Squint | style="background:lightgrey;" |   | Matt Smith | style="background:lightgrey;" |   |} ==Casting== [[File:Martin Freeman during filming of Sherlock cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Martin Freeman]] was cast as [[Bilbo Baggins|the titular character]].]] In early October 2010, it was confirmed by the studio that [[Martin Freeman]] had been cast in the role of [[Bilbo Baggins]]. It was revealed that he had earlier been approached by the producers to play a role in the films, but was forced to turn it down because of scheduling conflicts with the [[BBC]] television series ''[[Sherlock (TV series)|Sherlock]]''. At the time, Freeman was quoted as saying, "[I]f something could be worked out, that would be great. I did it [turned down the role] with a heavy heart, definitely."{{cite web |url= http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=29175 |title=Martin Freeman Talks The Hobbit | publisher =Empire Online |date=11 October 2010 |accessdate=30 April 2011}} On his casting, Peter Jackson was quoted as saying, "Despite the various rumours and speculation surrounding this role, there has only ever been one Bilbo Baggins for us. There are a few times in your career when you come across an actor who you know was born to play a role, but that was the case as soon as I met Martin Freeman. He is intelligent, funny, surprising and brave—exactly like Bilbo and I feel incredibly proud to be able to announce that he is our Hobbit."{{Cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11604193| title = Martin Freeman to play Bilbo Baggins in The Hobbit | date = 22 October 2010| publisher =BBC | work = News|accessdate=24 October 2010 | place = United Kingdom}} Later in October, it was revealed that several other cast members had joined the project, including [[Richard Armitage (actor)|Richard Armitage]] as [[Thorin Oakenshield]], [[Graham McTavish]] as [[Dwalin]], [[Aidan Turner]] as [[Kíli]], [[Mark Hadlow]] as [[Dori (Middle-earth)|Dori]], [[John Callen]] as [[Óin, son of Gróin|Óin]], [[Stephen Hunter (actor)|Stephen Hunter]] as [[Bombur (Middle-earth)|Bombur]] and [[Peter Hambleton]] as [[Glóin]]. On the casting of Armitage, Jackson was quoted as saying, "Richard is one of the most exciting and dynamic actors working on screen today and we know he is going to make an amazing Thorin Oakenshield. We cannot wait to start this adventure with him and feel very lucky that one of the most beloved characters in Middle Earth is in such good hands." McTavish was quoted on his casting, "I think that I would be very lucky indeed if ever again in my career, I was offered an opportunity that was going to be so iconic in its influence and scale with regards to ''The Hobbit''. I can't think of anything comparable."{{cite web|url= http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2010/12/09/41267-torn-exclusive-graham-dwalin-mctavish-interview/#more-41267 |title= Exclusive: Graham 'Dwalin' McTavish Interview |publisher=TheOneRing.net |date=9 December 2010 |accessdate= 30 April 2011}} Following McTavish's casting, scheduling conflicts arose while he was working on ''[[Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception]]'', resulting in the game's storyline being modified so that McTavish could go to New Zealand to work on the film. On the casting of Turner, Jackson stated, "Aidan is a wonderfully gifted young actor who hails from Ireland. I'm sure he will bring enormous heart and humor to the role of Kíli." On the casting of Hadlow, Jackson said, "I have worked with Mark Hadlow on many projects [''[[Meet the Feebles]]'' and ''[[King Kong (2005 film)|King Kong]]'']; he is a fantastic actor. I am thrilled to be working with [him] on these movies."{{Cite news |title=The Office's Martin Freeman as Bilbo Baggins leads Hobbit cast |work= The Australian |date= 21 January 2010 |first=Michael|last=Bodey |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/the-offices-martin-freeman-as-bilbo-baggins-leads-hobbit-cast/story-e6frg996-1225942288634 }}{{Cite news|first=Josh|last=Rottenberg|url = http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/10/21/the-hobbit-martin-freeman-to-play-bilbo/ |title='The Hobbit': Martin Freeman to play Bilbo Baggins; other roles also cast |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=21 October 2010 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} Hadlow also plays Bert the [[Olog-hai|Stone-troll]]. On his casting Callen stated, "I did wonder about my casting and how they had made the choice—maybe the long hair and the beard sold it, I thought. But now that has all gone. Given that Óin is almost 200 years old I can presume only that it was the age."{{cite web|url = http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2010/11/20/40586-exclusive-getting-to-know-john-callen-aka-oin/#more-40586 |title= Getting to know John Callen aka Óin|publisher=TheOneRing.net |date=20 November 2010 |accessdate= 1 May 2011}} On being cast in the role, Hunter said, "Being cast in ''The Hobbit'' is really exciting and really an honour. I auditioned for the original ''Lord of the Rings'' way back when I signed with my agent in New Zealand. When I saw the films I thought, 'Man, I so want to do ''The Hobbit''.'"{{cite web|url = http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2010/10/31/39979-torn-exclusive-an-interview-with-stephen-hunterbombur/ |title= Exclusive: an interview with Stephen Hunter/Bombur |publisher = TheOneRing.net |date= 31 October 2010|accessdate= 1 May 2011}} On 1 November 2010, Jackson confirmed that [[James Nesbitt]] and [[Adam Brown (actor)|Adam Brown]] had been added to the cast to play [[Bofur]] and [[Ori (Middle-earth)|Ori]] respectively.{{Cite news |url= http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=71316 |agency=Crave|date= 1 November 2010 |accessdate=1 November 2010 |title=James Nesbitt and Adam Brown Join ''The Hobbit''}} It was previously reported that Nesbitt was in negotiations for a part in the film.{{Cite news |first=Michael|last=Speier |url= http://www.deadline.com/2010/10/the-hobbit-finally-starts-filming-in-february/ |agency=Deadline Hollywood |date=15 October 2010 |accessdate=16 October 2010 |title='The Hobbit' Finally Filming in February, But Peter Jackson & Actor Unions Still at Odds}} Jackson was quoted on Nesbitt's casting as saying, "James's charm, warmth and wit are legendary as is his range as an actor in both comedic and dramatic roles. We feel very lucky to be able to welcome him as one of our cast." Nesbitt's daughters also appear in the film series as Sigrid and Tilda, the daughters of Bard the Bowman. Commenting on Brown's casting, Jackson was quoted as saying, "Adam is a wonderfully expressive actor and has a unique screen presence. I look forward to seeing him bring Ori to life." The role also marked Brown's first film appearance.{{Cite news |url = http://www.newburytoday.co.uk/News/Article.aspx?articleID=15020 |agency = Newbury Today |date = 4 November 2010 |accessdate = 1 May 2011 |title = Hobbit role for Hungerford actor |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101209020851/http://www.newburytoday.co.uk/News/Article.aspx?articleID=15020 |archivedate = 9 December 2010 |df = dmy-all }} On 7 December 2010, it was revealed that several other cast members had joined the project, including [[Cate Blanchett]] as [[Galadriel]], [[Sylvester McCoy]] as [[Radagast|Radagast the Brown]], [[Mikael Persbrandt]] as [[Beorn]], [[William Kircher]] as [[Bifur]], [[Ken Stott]] as [[Balin (Middle-earth)|Balin]] and [[Jed Brophy]] as [[Nori (Middle-earth)|Nori]].{{Cite news|url= http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2010/12/07/41135-torn-exclusive-cate-blanchett-ken-stott-sylvester-mccoy-mikael-persbrandt-join-cast-of-peter-jackson%E2%80%99s-%E2%80%9Cthe-hobbit%E2%80%9D/ |date=7 December 2010|accessdate=7 December 2010|publisher= TheOneRing.net| title = TORN Exclusive: Cate Blanchett, Ken Stott, Sylvester McCoy, Mikael Persbrandt join cast of Peter Jackson’s ‘The Hobbit’}} Blanchett was the first returning cast member from [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'' film trilogy]] to be cast in the films, even though her character does not appear in the novel. On her casting, Jackson said, "Cate is one of my favorite actors to work with and I couldn't be more thrilled to have her reprise the role she so beautifully brought to life in the earlier films." McCoy, the former ''[[Doctor Who]]'' star, who appeared alongside McKellen in a [[Royal Shakespeare Company]]'s [[King Lear (2008 TV film)|King Lear]], was confirmed to be in negotiations to play a major role as a "wizard" in October 2010,{{Cite news|url= http://www.dunoon-observer.com/index.php/news/1-news/827-chieftain-confirms-exciting-new-role=%22_blank%22 |title= Cowal Games Exclusive |date= 28 August 2010 |accessdate = 29 August 2010 |agency=Dunoon Observer}} leading to speculation he could appear as Radagast the Brown.{{Cite news |url= http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2010/08/28/38114-sylvester-mccoy-up-for-radagast-the-brown/ |publisher= TheOneRing.net |title=Sylvester McCoy up for Radagast the Brown? |date=28 August 2010 |accessdate=29 August 2010}} During the production of ''The Lord of the Rings'' film trilogy, McCoy had been contacted about playing the role of Bilbo and was kept in place as a potential Bilbo for six months before Jackson went with Ian Holm.{{Cite news | first = Diane | last = Parkes |title=Who's that playing The Mikado? |work=[[Birmingham Mail]] |date=19 September 2008|url = http://www.birminghammail.net/what-is-on-in-birmingham/theatre-in-birmingham/2008/09/19/who-s-that-playing-the-mikado-97319-21855947/ |accessdate=22 September 2008}} On the casting of Persbrandt, Jackson was quoted as saying, "The role of Beorn is an iconic one and Mikael was our first choice for the part. Since seeing him read for the role we can't imagine anyone else playing this character." On the casting of Stott, Jackson commented "[[Fran Walsh|Fran]] and I have long been fans of Ken's work and are excited he will be joining us on this journey." The casting of Brophy came after his collaboration with Jackson on several films, including ''[[Braindead (film)|Braindead]]'', ''[[Heavenly Creatures]]'', and [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|all three ''Lord of the Rings'' films]] as various creatures. On 7 January 2011, [[TheOneRing.net]] confirmed that [[Elijah Wood]] had joined the cast to reprise his role of [[Frodo Baggins]] in the project. As Frodo hadn't been born during the events of ''The Hobbit'', the inclusion of Frodo indicated that parts of the story would take place shortly before or during the events of ''The Lord of the Rings''. According to TheOneRing.net, "As readers of 'The Hobbit' know, the tale of 'The Downfall of The Lord of the Rings' and 'The Hobbit or There and Back Again,' are contained in the fictional '[[Red Book of Westmarch]].' In Peter Jackson's LOTR films, the book is shown on screen and written in by Bilbo and Frodo and handed off to [[Samwise Gamgee]] .... The fictional book and either the telling from it or the reading of it, will establish Frodo in the film experiencing Bilbo's story. Viewers are to learn the tale of 'The Hobbit' as a familiar Frodo gets the tale as well."{{Cite news |url= http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2011/01/07/41520-elijah-wood-will-be-in-the-hobbit/ |agency=TheOneRing.net |title=Elijah Wood will be in 'The Hobbit' (and we know how!) |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=7 January 2011}} [[File:Ian McKellen.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Ian McKellen]] returned as the [[Wizard (Middle-earth)|wizard]] [[Gandalf]].]] On 10 January 2011, it was confirmed that [[Ian McKellen]] and [[Andy Serkis]] would reprise their respective roles of [[Gandalf|Gandalf the Grey]] and [[Gollum]] from [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'' film trilogy]].{{cite web|title=Ian McKellen and Andy Serkis join cast of The Hobbit|url=http://www.totalfilm.com/news/ian-mckellen-and-andy-serkis-join-the-hobbit|publisher=Total Film|accessdate=28 November 2013}} Although both actors were expected to return for their roles McKellen was previously quoted in July 2010 on [[TVNZ]]'s ''[[Good Morning (New Zealand TV series)|Good Morning]]'' that: "I'm not under contract and my time is running out. I don't want to give the producers the impression that I'm sitting waiting."{{Citation | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wAr1nLcmqeQ | first = Ian | last = McKellen | type = video | publisher = TVNZ | title = Good Morning }} It was later revealed that Serkis would also serve as [[second unit director]] on the films.{{Cite news |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/gollum-actor-andy-serkis-serve-175685 |agency= The Hollywood Reporter |date= 6 April 2011 |accessdate= 1 May 2011 |title= Gollum Actor Andy Serkis to Serve as Second Unit Director on 'The Hobbit' (Exclusive) |first=Carolyn|last=Giardina}} Serkis stated, "I think I understand Peter's sensibility and we have a common history of understanding Middle-earth. A lot of the crew from ''The Lord of the Rings'' was returning to work on ''The Hobbit''. There is really a sense of Peter wanting people around him who totally understand the material and the work ethic." On 11 January 2011, it was confirmed that [[Christopher Lee]] would reprise his role as [[Saruman|Saruman the White]].{{Cite news |url = http://christopherleeweb.com/story/sir-christopher-returns-hobbit |agency = Christopher Lee Official Website |title = Sir Christopher Returns in The Hobbit |date = 11 January 2011 |accessdate = 11 January 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110115011730/http://christopherleeweb.com/story/sir-christopher-returns-hobbit |archivedate = 15 January 2011 |df = dmy-all }} Lee had originally said he would have liked to have shown how Saruman is first corrupted by [[Sauron]],{{cite news | first = Glen | last = Ferris | title = Christopher Lee on ''The Hobbit'' | work = [[Empire (film magazine)|Empire Online]] | date = 4 June 2008 | url = http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=22681 | accessdate = 4 June 2008}} but would not be comfortable flying to New Zealand at his age.{{Cite news| first =Elisabeth | last = Rappe | title = Looks Like Christopher Lee Might Not Return to Middle-Earth |work=Cinematical |date=13 July 2008|url = http://www.cinematical.com/2008/07/13/christopher-lee-wont-return-to-middle-earth/ | accessdate= 14 July 2008}} Lee went on to say that if a film were made, he would love to voice [[Smaug]], as it would mean he could record his part in England and not have to travel.{{cite web|title=Christopher Lee about possibly returning to Middle Earth| work = You tube | publisher = Google | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5qGFbBNnodw&feature=player_embedded | accessdate= 23 December 2010}} On 10 January 2011, it was reported that Lee had entered into negotiations to reprise the role of Saruman. On 21 March 2011, [[Jeffrey Thomas (actor)|Jeffrey Thomas]] joined the project as the character of [[Thrór]], as did Mike Mizrahi as [[Thráin II]].{{cite news |title=''The Hobbit'' begins production in New Zealand |first=Simon |last=Reynolds |url= http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/news/a310107/the-hobbit-begins-production-in-new-zealand.html |publisher=[[Digital Spy]] |date=21 March 2011 |accessdate=29 March 2011}} On 4 April 2011, [[Bret McKenzie]] was added to the cast as [[Lindir]].{{Cite news |first= David ‘Dave’ |last=McNary |url= http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118034972|title= 'Conchords' star McKenzie an elf in 'The Hobbit' |work= Variety |date=4 April 2011 |accessdate=4 April 2011}} His father [[Peter McKenzie (actor)|Peter McKenzie]] played the role of [[Elendil]] in ''The Lord of the Rings''. On 22 April 2011, Jackson confirmed via Facebook that [[Ian Holm]] had been added to the cast as old Bilbo Baggins.{{cite web|url= http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/04/22/the-hobbit-ian-holm-is-officially-in-as-old-bilbo/ |title=The Hobbit: Ian Holm is officially in as old Bilbo|publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=22 April 2011| accessdate = 22 April 2011}} During the early stages of pre-production, former director [[Guillermo del Toro]] indicated that he was interested in having Holm reprise the role of Bilbo, but acknowledged that he might be too old to take on such a physically demanding role. On his potential casting, del Toro stated, "[Holm] certainly is the paragon we aspire to. He will be involved in some manner, I'm sure."{{cite news | first = Shawn | last = Adler | title = Guillermo Del Toro Addresses 'Hobbit' Fans' Concerns, Talks Possible Casting | work = MTV | date = 28 April 2008 | url = http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1586421/story.jhtml | accessdate=30 April 2008}} He also indicated that he was open to the possibility of Holm narrating the films. On 10 January 2011, Deadline Hollywood reported that Holm had entered into negotiations to play the older Bilbo.{{Cite news|url = http://www.deadline.com/2011/01/andy-serkis-signed-to-reprise-gollum-in-the-hobbit/ |agency=Deadline Hollywood|title=Andy Serkis Signed To Reprise Gollum In 'The Hobbit'|date= 10 January 2011|accessdate= 11 January 2011}} On 3 March 2011, Holm revealed that he had been in talks with the producers about reprising the role, but that he had not heard back from them yet.{{Cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/8357397/Sir-Ian-Holm-left-out-in-the-cold-as-The-Hobbit-starts-filming.html | title = Sir Ian Holm left out in the cold as The Hobbit starts filming| publisher= The Telegraph | location = London | date = 3 March 2011| accessdate= 30 April 2011 |first= Timothy ‘Tim’ |last= Walker}} In the early stages of production, the role of [[Thranduil]] had been linked to actor [[Doug Jones (actor)|Doug Jones]] but on 29 April 2011, Jackson reported on Facebook that the role had gone to [[Lee Pace]]. On his casting, Jackson said, "Casting these Tolkien stories is very difficult, especially the Elven characters and Lee has always been our first choice for Thranduil. He's going to be great. We loved his performance in a movie called ''[[The Fall (2006 film)|The Fall]]'' a few years ago and have been hoping to work with him since. When we were first discussing who would be right for Thranduil, Lee came into mind almost immediately."{{cite web |url= http://popwatch.ew.com/2011/05/02/lee-pace-cast-in-the-hobbit-our-hopes-for-his-comeback-grow/ |work = Entertainment Weekly |title=Lee Pace cast in 'The Hobbit.' Our hopes for his comeback grow |first=Sandra|last=Gonzalez |date=2 May 2011 |accessdate=2 May 2011}} On 30 April 2011, Jackson announced that [[Dean O'Gorman]] had been hired for the role of [[Fíli]].{{cite web |first=Peter|last=Jackson |url = http://www.facebook.com/notes/peter-jackson/casting-news/10150239464391558 |title=Casting news! |work=Facebook |date=30 April 2011 |accessdate=30 April 2011}} Jackson stated, "Dean's a terrific [[Kiwi (people)|Kiwi]] actor, who I am thrilled to be working with." O'Gorman was a last minute replacement for [[Robert Kazinsky|Rob Kazinsky]] had originally been cast for the role in October 2010, but left the film on 24 April 2011 "for personal reasons".{{cite web |url= http://www.ew.com/article/2011/04/24/the-hobbit-rob-kazinsky-fili |title='The Hobbit': Actor Rob Kazinsky, cast as dwarf Fili, drops out of movie |last=Vary|first=Adam |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=24 April 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2011}} [[Hugo Weaving]]'s return to the role of [[Elrond]] was officially confirmed on 1 May 2011.{{Cite news|url = http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/film/4948801/Kiwi-actor-steps-into-Hobbit-breach |agency=The Dominion Post|title=Kiwi actor steps into Hobbit breach|date=2 May 2011|accessdate= 2 May 2011}} [[File:Benedict Cumberbatch 2011 (jpg).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Benedict Cumberbatch]], the [[Dragon (Middle-earth)|dragon]] [[Smaug]] and [[Sauron|The Necromancer]].]] On 19 May 2011, [[Stephen Fry]] and Ryan Gage were confirmed to join the project as [[Master of Lake-town]] and Alfrid respectively.{{cite web|publisher= Facebook| date= 19 May 2011 | accessdate = 19 May 2011| url= http://www.facebook.com/notes/peter-jackson/hobbit-casting-news/10150257180211558| title = Hobbit Casting News|first=Peter|last=Jackson}} Fry spoke of his role, saying "My character is an opportunity for sheer grossness .... [Peter Jackson] had me eating testicles ... gross appetites. I mustn't give too much away but I've got a bald cap and then on top of that a really bad combover wig and this wispy mustache and wispy beard and horrible blotchy skin and disgusting fingernails .... And generally speaking a really unappetising piece of work. And a coward to boot and very, very greedy."{{cite web|url= http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/news/a356330/sherlock-holmess-stephen-fry-i-ate-testicles-for-the-hobbit.html | work =Digital Spy|title='Sherlock Holmes's Stephen Fry: 'I ate testicles for The Hobbit'|first=Stella|last=Papamichael|date= 16 December 2011|accessdate=27 December 2011}} Gage was originally cast to play [[Drogo Baggins]] in December 2010, though according to Jackson, "Ryan is a great young actor who we originally cast in a small role, but we liked him so much, we promoted him to the much larger Alfrid part". On 27 May 2011, Peter Jackson announced via Facebook that [[Orlando Bloom]] would reprise his role as [[Legolas]].{{Citation | url = http://www.facebook.com/notes/the-hobbit/orlando-bloom-joins-the-cast-of-the-hobbit/205391369496476 | contribution = Orlando Bloom Joins the Cast of ‘The Hobbit’ | title = Facebook}} Bloom revealed on 25 April 2011 that he had been in contact with Jackson, who had given him a copy of the screenplay and said that there was a high probability that he would return. He was quoted as saying, "I'm going to bet on it .... But I can't really talk too much about it because it's still sort of in the ether. But I would love to go back to work with Peter Jackson. It would be an honour."{{Cite news|url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1662649/orlando-bloom-the-hobbit.jhtml |agency=MTV|date=25 April 2011|accessdate= 30 April 2011 |title=Orlando Bloom Says It's A Good 'Bet' He'll Be In 'The Hobbit'}} 19 June 2011, it was revealed that several other cast members had joined the project, including [[Luke Evans (actor)|Luke Evans]] in the role of [[Bard the Bowman]], [[Evangeline Lilly]] as [[Tauriel]], [[Barry Humphries]] as the [[Great Goblin]] and [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] as [[Smaug]] and [[Sauron|The Necromancer]].{{cite news|url=http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2011/06/19/45296-pj-confirms-evans-and-cumberbatch-announces-losts-evangeline-lilly-and-barry-humphries|work=TheOneRing.net|title=PJ Confirms Evans and Cumberbatch, Announces 'Lost'{{'}}s Evangeline Lilly and Barry Humphries|date=19 June 2011|accessdate=19 June 2011}} Cumberbatch portrayed both of his roles through [[motion capture]], as did Humphries for his character.{{Citation | url = http://www.benedictcumberbatch.co.uk/benedict-cumberbatch-and-louise-brealey-discuss-sherlock-at-cheltenham-literary-festival | title = Benedict Cumberbatch and Louise Brealey discuss Sherlock at Cheltenham Literary Festival | place = United Kingdom | type = interview | publisher = Benedict Cumberbatch}} The casting of Cumberbatch was prematurely revealed by his ''[[Sherlock (TV series)|Sherlock]]'' co-star [[Martin Freeman]] during the [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] Television Awards in May 2011. Speculations of his undisclosed role were further fuelled when [[Ian McKellen]] wrote on his blog that [[Philippa Boyens]] showed him Cumberbatch's screen test, stating that it was "electrifying, vocally and facially".{{Citation | url = http://www.mckellen.com/cinema/hobbit-movie/110531.htm | last = McKellen |first= Ian | title=Congratulations, dear Watson | date= 31 May 2011 | accessdate= 26 November 2012}} Peter Jackson finally revealed on his Facebook page that Cumberbatch was set to play Smaug. Following this, it was also confirmed that he would be portraying The Necromancer as well.{{Cite news | url = http://www.deadline.com/2011/06/benedict-cumberbatch-to-voice-smaug-in-the-hobbit/ | first=Mike, Jr. | last=Fleming| work= Deadline | title= Benedict Cumberbatch to voice Smaug in ''The Hobbit'' | date= June 2011 | accessdate= 26 November 2012 }} [[Billy Connolly]] joined the cast as [[Dáin II Ironfoot]] on 9 February 2012.{{cite web |title=Billy Connolly joins The Hobbit cast |url=http://www.wetanz.com/billy-conolly-joins-the-hobbit-cast |publisher=Weta |location=NZ |date=9 February 2012 |accessdate=9 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212001211/http://www.wetanz.com/billy-conolly-joins-the-hobbit-cast |archivedate=12 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Connolly said of his character "... this guy will terrify the life out of you. I have a mohawk and tattoos on my head."{{cite web |url= http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2012/06/18/57504-analysing-billy-connollys-dain-ironfoot/ |publisher= TheOneRing.net |title='Analysing Billy Connolly's Dain Ironfoot'| date=18 June 2012 |accessdate = 20 June 2012}} In addition, [[John Bell (Scottish actor)|John Bell]] plays [[Bain (Middle-earth)|Bain]],{{cite web |first=Brendan|last=Connelly |title=Exactly One Year Before The Hobbit Opens, The Official Blurb Is Unveiled |url= http://www.bleedingcool.com/2011/12/14/exactly-one-year-before-hobbit-opens-official-blurb-unveiled/ |publisher=Bleeding Cool |date=14 December 2011 |accessdate= 14 December 2011}}{{cite web |title=John Bell discusses his role in ‘A shine of rainbows’ available now on DVD |url=http://hollywoodteenzine.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1913&Itemid=87 |publisher=Hollywood Teen 'Zine |date=14 December 2011 |accessdate=14 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111062612/http://hollywoodteenzine.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1913&Itemid=87 |archivedate=11 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }} [[Manu Bennett]] plays [[Azog]],{{Citation | url = http://lucylucretia.blogspot.co.uk/2012/08/manu-bennett-in-hobbit.html | title = Lucy Lucretia | contribution = Manu Bennett in ‘Hobbit’ |date=August 2012 | publisher = Google | type = [[World Wide Web]] log | place = United Kingdom}} [[Craig Hall (actor)|Craig Hall]] plays [[Galion (Middle-earth)|Galion]],{{Cite news |url= http://www.actors.co.nz/viewPage.aspx?documentId=40019 |title= The Hobbit: an unexpected hourney |publisher= Karen Kay Management |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140120173050/http://www.actors.co.nz/viewpage.aspx?documentid=40019 |archivedate= 20 January 2014 |df= dmy-all }} [[Benjamin Mitchell (actor)|Ben Mitchell]] plays Narzug, [[John Rawls (actor)|John Rawls]] plays Yazneg,{{Citation | url = http://www.theonering.net/torwp/the-hobbit/characters/60453-2/ | title = Yazneg | publisher = TheOneRing.net }} Stephen Ure plays Fimbul and Grinnah, [[Kiran Shah]] plays a goblin scribe,{{cite news |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/hobbit-an-unexpected-journey/cast-crew#cast |title=Cast & Crew |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=12 December 2012}} and [[Stephen Colbert]] was cast in an undisclosed cameo.{{cite news | url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/stephen-colbert-make-hobbit-cameo-381423 | title = Stephen Colbert to Make Cameo in 'The Hobbit' | accessdate=20 October 2012 | work=The Hollywood Reporter | first=Kim | last=Masters | date=20 October 2012}} [[Conan Stevens]] was to play [[Bolg]],{{Citation | url = http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2012/05/30/56472-conan-stevens-is-giving-away-his-official-the-hobbit-production-shirt/ |publisher=TheOneRing.net| date = 30 May 2012 | title = Conan Stevens is giving away his official ‘The Hobbit’ production shirt}} but he eventually played a Gundabad Orc, also known as Keeper of Dungeons. ==Filming== [[File:Baggins residence 'Bag End' with party sign.jpg|thumb|The Lord of the Rings movie set of Hobbiton (including "Bag End", pictured) near Matamata was renovated and re-used for filming The Hobbit]] [[Principal photography]] began on 21 March 2011 in [[Wellington|Wellington, New Zealand]]. Filming took place at Wellington Stone Street Studios, the town of [[Matamata]] and at other undisclosed locations around New Zealand.{{Cite news| last =Bulbeck| first =Pip| date =20 March 2011| title ='Hobbit' Filming Finally Under Way in New Zealand| url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/hobbit-filming-finally-under-way-169449| work = [[The Hollywood Reporter]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5xLimLrIb?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/hobbit-filming-finally-begins-new-169449| archivedate = 21 March 2011| accessdate = 21 March 2011}} The costumes for each of the Dwarves included six [[wig]]s and eight beards, which were worn by the actors, stunt doubles, and stand-ins.{{cite news |last=Masters|first=Kim |title='The Hobbit:' Inside Peter Jackson and Warner Bros.' $1 Billion Gamble |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/the-hobbit-peter-jackson-warner-bros-1-billion-79301 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=17 October 2012 |date=17 October 2012}} During July 2011, scenes from ''The Hobbit'' were filmed at [[Pinewood Studios]], England. Sets were constructed on the F Stage and N&P Stages for the shoot.{{cite web |title= Hobbits at Pinewood |url= http://www.pinewoodgroup.com/2011/07/hobbits-at-pinewood |date= 22 July 2011 |accessdate= 20 August 2011 |work= Pinewood Studios |publisher= Pinewood Shepperton Plc |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111002224217/http://www.pinewoodgroup.com/about-us/news/hobbit-pinewood |archivedate= 2 October 2011 |df= dmy-all }} Jackson recorded a video blog from the set, which featured [[Christopher Lee]] in full makeup and costume as Saruman.{{cite web |title= Production Video No. 3 |url= http://www.thehobbitblog.com/?p=3133 |author= The Hobbit Team |work=The Hobbit Blog |date= 21 July 2011 |accessdate= 22 August 2011}} The second block of shooting in New Zealand began at the end of August and was completed in December 2011.{{cite web |url= http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2011/08/23/47542-the-hobbit-filming-resumes/ |title=The Hobbit Filming Resumes |work=Theonering.net |date=23 August 2011 |accessdate=6 September 2012}} Principal photography ended on 6 July 2012, after 266 days of filming.{{cite news |last=Zakarin|first=Jordan |title='The Hobbit' Completes Filming, Peter Jackson Posts Facebook Message (Photo) |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/hobbit-completes-filming-peter-jackson-lord-of-the-rings-345996 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=17 October 2012 |date=6 July 2012}} During May 2013, additional filming for the second and third films began in New Zealand and lasted for 10 weeks.{{cite web |title=Confirmed: 'Hobbit' Filming Resumes Monday.|url=http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2013/05/16/71682-confirmed-hobbit-filming-resumes-monday/|date=25 May 2013 |accessdate=25 May 2012}} ===Filming locations=== {| class="wikitable" |+ A list of filming locations |- ! Aspiring Rd || Wanaka |} ===Technology=== {{See also|3D film|High Frame Rate}} [[File:John Howe and Alan Lee - 3D concept art.png|thumb|3D concept art by [[John Howe (illustrator)|John Howe]] and [[Alan Lee (illustrator)|Alan Lee]]]] [[File:Comparison of 5K to standard resolution.png|thumb|right|Comparison of 5K to standard resolution]] The films were filmed in 3D using [[Red Digital Cinema Camera Company|Red]] Epic cameras.{{Cite news | last =Carlyle| first= Erin|date= 15 December 2012 |title= 'The Hobbit' Director Peter Jackson: How Billionaire Jim Jannard Made The Film Possible| url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/erincarlyle/2012/12/15/the-hobbit-director-peter-jackson-how-billionaire-jim-jannard-made-the-film-possible/|work=[[/Film]]|accessdate=7 January 2012}} According to a production diary video, 48 Epic cameras were used during the film's production. The production employed a specialty rig designed by [[3ality Technica]], using two cameras and a mirror in order to achieve an intraocular effect similar to that of human sight (the distance between the eyes). This is how the depth required for 3D film is achieved.{{cite web|title= Production Video #4|url= http://www.thehobbitblog.com/?p=3933 | publisher = The Hobbit Team|work=The Hobbit Blog|date= 5 November 2011}} In April 2011, Jackson revealed through his Facebook page that he would film ''The Hobbit'' at 48 [[Frame rate|fps]] (frames per second) instead of the normal 24 fps.{{cite web | last =Sciretta| first= Peter|date= 11 April 2011 |title= Peter Jackson Explains Why He's Shooting 'The Hobbit' at 48 Frames Per Second| url = http://www.slashfilm.com/peter-jackson-explains-shooting-the-hobbit-48-frames|work=[[/Film]]|accessdate=12 April 2011}} Additionally, the films were filmed at a 5K [[image resolution|resolution]], native to the Red Epic cameras, which provides a more detailed picture than the conventional 4K resolution. The films were recorded digitally onto 128 GB [[solid-state drive]]s that fit into the Red Epic camera. ===Alleged animal abuse=== [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]] (PETA) asked the New Zealand government to investigate allegations that 27 animals used for the film died due to poor living conditions. Claims also include sheep falling into sinkholes, chickens being mauled by unsupervised dogs, a horse falling over a steep embankment, and another one being left on the ground for three hours after being hobbled. PETA says that instead of "vainly defending himself", Peter Jackson should be giving a "firm assurance that this will never happen again". They also called Jackson a "CGI master", stating that he could easily make convincing CGI animals, instead of using actual ones.{{cite web|url=http://www.peta.org/features/the-hobbit-unexpected-cruelty.aspx |title=The Hobbit: Unexpected Cruelty |publisher=PETA.org |date= |accessdate=25 December 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/366227/hobbit-brouhaha-peta-now-demanding-new-zealand-government-probe-animal-abuse-allegations |title=Hobbit Brouhaha: PETA Now Demanding New Zealand Government Probe Animal Abuse Allegations |publisher=E! Online |date=27 November 2012 |accessdate=25 December 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/19/hobbit-animal-deaths-wranglers_n_2158198.html |title='Hobbit' Animal Deaths: Up To 27 Die As Wranglers Blame Production Company |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 19 November 2012|accessdate=25 December 2012}} Peter Jackson denied these allegations in a press conference hours before the premiere of the first film stating that there was "Absolutely none; no mistreatment, no abuse".{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/11/peter-jackson-again-denies-the-hobbit-animal-cruelty-claims-before-premiere/ |title=Peter Jackson Again Denies Animal Abuse Claim Before Hobbit Premiere |website=Deadline Hollywood |date= |accessdate=27 January 2014}} Warner Bros. also released a statement which joined Peter Jackson in denying the allegations, questioning the timing and claiming the primary source of the allegations could be traced to freelance animal wranglers who had been dismissed by the production over a year earlier "for cause".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/nov/23/hobbit-animal-abuse-warner-bros/ |first=Ben |last=Child |title=Hobbit animal abuse claims: Warner Bros backs Peter Jackson |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=23 November 2012 |accessdate=27 January 2014}} ==Post-production== ===Music=== {{Main|Music of The Hobbit film series}} The music of ''The Hobbit'' film series was composed, produced and (in the case of the first film) orchestrated and conducted by [[Howard Shore]], who scored all three [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'' films]]. Recording sessions for the first film began on 20 August 2012, at [[Abbey Road Studios]].{{cite web|title=On The Hobbit Recording Sessions & Doug Adams’ Book "The Music Of The Hobbit Films"|url=http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2012/08/20/61016-on-the-hobbit-recording-sessions-doug-adams-book-the-music-of-the-hobbit-films/|publisher=[[TheOneRing.net]]|accessdate=29 November 2013}} The second and third films were recorded in New Zealand.{{cite web|title=NZSO to record Desolation of Smaug soundtrack|url=http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2013/07/13/75587-nzso-to-record-desolation-of-smaug-soundtrack/|publisher=[[TheOneRing.net]]|accessdate=29 November 2013}} Unlike with the Lord of the Rings, which only received an expanded release after 2005, each Hobbit soundtrack was released in a two-CD, two-hour release. The music features 64-70 new [[Leitmotif|leitmotives]], about 40 leitmotives returning from The Lord of the Rings, and a variety of non-orchestral instruments, including [[bagpipes]], [[didgeridoo]]s and a whole [[Gamelan]] orchestra.see [[Music of The Hobbit film series|music of the Hobbit film series]]. The score for ''An Unexpected Journey'' was primarily played by the [[London Philharmonic Orchestra]] (as it was for ''The Lord of the Rings''), London Voices and Tiffin' Boys choir, although Jackson and Shore chose the [[New Zealand Symphony Orchestra]] (which participated in scoring a large section of the Fellowship of the Ring) to score ''The Desolation of Smaug'' and ''The Battle of the Five Armies''. Additional musicians, including two [[gamelan]] orchestras, and the London Voices and Tiffin' boys choir, augmented the orchestra. Musicians [[Neil Finn]] and [[Ed Sheeran]] contributed to the score as well as some actors including [[Richard Armitage (actor)|Richard Armitage]] and the cast of dwarves, [[James Nesbitt]] and [[Barry Humphries]] (in the extended edition).{{cite web|title=The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey – Extended Edition REVIEW|url=http://www.sfx.co.uk/2013/11/08/the-hobbit-an-unexpected-journey-extended-edition-review/|publisher=sfx.co.uk|accessdate=29 November 2013}} Clara Sanabras{{cite web|url=http://clarasanabras.co.uk/project/the-hobbit-an-unexpected-journey/|title=The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey - clarasanabras.co.uk|first=|last=alaricking.co.uk|website=clarasanabras.co.uk}} and Grace Davidson{{cite web|url=https://thewest.com.au/entertainment/art/rising-soprano-in-waso-ring-quest-ng-ya-372729|title=Rising soprano in WASO ring quest|date=18 June 2014|publisher=}} sang the soprano parts. ===Visual effects=== As with [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'' trilogy]], [[Weta Digital]] was involved in the creation of special effects. However, as opposed to ''The Lord of the Rings'', where the actors who played Orcs portrayed them through full-body makeup and prosthetics, many of those actors in ''The Hobbit'' had [[Computer-generated imagery|computer-generated]] faces in order to portray them.{{cite web |title=Behind the scenes of The Hobbit |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/film/7932722/Behind-the-scenes-of-The-Hobbit |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |accessdate=12 November 2012}} Many of the actors who played Orcs in this trilogy portrayed them through [[performance capture]]. {{cite web |title=Here’s How ‘The Hobbit’ Dragon Looks Without Visual Effects| url= http://www.businessinsider.com/hobbit-benedict-cumberbatch-motion-capture-smaug-2014-12 |publisher=Businessinsider |accessdate=18 December 2014}}{{cite web |title=Bringing The Battle of the Five Armies to the screen | url= https://www.fxguide.com/featured/bringing-the-battle-of-the-five-armies-to-the-screen/|publisher=Fxguide.com |accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web |title=The Hobbit: Weta returns to Middle-earth| url= https://www.fxguide.com/featured/the-hobbit-weta/|publisher=Fxguide.com |accessdate=14 December 2012}} ==Release== ===Theatrical=== [[File:The Hobbit - An Unexpected Journey premiere.jpg|thumb|right|A [[standee]] outside the Embassy Theatre in [[Wellington|Wellington, New Zealand]] at the world premiere of ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey''.]] The world premiere for ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey'' took place on 28 November 2012 in [[Wellington]], New Zealand,{{cite news| last = Bulbeck| first = Pip | title = New Zealanders to See 'The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey' on Nov. 28 | url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/new-zealanders-see-hobbit-an-334183 | work= The Hollywood Reporter| accessdate = 24 September 2012 |date= 6 June 2012}} with the film's wide release in New Zealand on 12 December.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/nov/28/hobbit-premiere-peter-jackson-wellington |title= The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey overcomes setbacks for premiere |date= 28 November 2012 |work=Guardian UK |accessdate=29 November 2012 |location=London |first=Ben |last=Child}} 100,000 people lined the red carpet on Wellington's Courtenay Place for the premiere.{{cite news| url= http://3news.co.nz/100000-expected-at-Hobbit-premiere-celebrations/tabid/418/articleID/278352/Default.aspx |work=3 News NZ |title=100,000 expected at Hobbit premiere| date=28 November 2012}} The entire event was also broadcast live on TV3 and streamed over the Internet.{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Entertainment/TheHobbit/Livestream.aspx |work=3 News NZ |title=Live Stream of the Hobbit Premiere| date=28 November 2012}} Tickets to the film's midnight screenings in New Zealand sold out within minutes of going on sale, prompting director Peter Jackson to say that the fans who missed out "may get something special" which could include getting to see the film "possibly even a minute or two before anyone else".{{Citation | title = Stuff | url = http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/film/7916437/Sir-Peter-saves-the-day-for-disappointed-Hobbit-fans | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130223025559/http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/film/7916437/Sir-Peter-saves-the-day-for-disappointed-Hobbit-fans | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2013-02-23 | contribution = Sir Peter saves the day for disappointed Hobbit fans | place = [[New Zealand|NZ]] }} The film was released on 13 December 2012 in the United Kingdom{{Citation | title = Facebook | contribution = The Hobbit | place = United Kingdom | type = announcement | date = 19 October 2012 | url = https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=432623330118202&set=a.377113225669213.81910.175992219114649&type=1&theater}} and 14 December 2012 for some other parts of the world. It has a runtime of 169 minutes (2 hours and 49 minutes).{{cite web |title=''THE HOBBIT – AN UNEXPECTED JOURNEY'' (12A) |url= http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/hobbit-unexpected-journey-2012-3 |work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |date=29 November 2012 |accessdate=29 November 2012}} The film grossed over $1 billion at the box office, surpassing both ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring|The Fellowship of the Ring]]'' and ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers|The Two Towers]]'' nominally.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/world/|title=All Time Box Office|accessdate=22 March 2013}} ''The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug'' premiered on 2 December 2013 in [[Los Angeles]], and was released internationally from 11 December 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehobbit.com/releasedates/index.html|title=The Hobbit Worldwide Release Dates | publisher=thehobbit.com | accessdate=7 September 2013}} It grossed over $958 million in box office worldwide. Like the previous installment, it surpassed both ''The Fellowship of the Ring'' and ''The Two Towers'' in nominal box office performance.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=2013&p=.htm|title=2013 WORLDWIDE GROSSES|accessdate=13 January 2017}} The final film ''The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies'' premiered on 11 December 2014 in London, and was released internationally from 12 December 2014. The release for the third film was originally set for an 18 July 2014 release, but was pushed back when ''[[X-Men: Days of Future Past]]'', was announced to be released on the same date, as direct competition to the third installment.{{cite web|url=http://www.theonering.com/news/the-hobbit-movies/the-hobbit-part-3-delayed-5-months-to-release-december-17-2014 |title=The Hobbit Part 3 Release Delayed 5 Months, To Release December 17, 2014 |publisher=Theonering.com |date=1 March 2013 |accessdate=16 May 2014}} It grossed over $956 million in worldwide level in box office, and as the previous two films, it surpassed both ''The Fellowship of the Ring'' and ''The Two Towers'' nominally, although it didn't manage to surpass the previous two films of the series. ===Home media=== ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey'' was released on [[3D Blu-ray]], [[Blu-ray]] and DVD in United States on 19 March 2013, and was released in the United Kingdom on 8 April 2013. As of 7 July 2013, DVD/Blu-ray sales in the United States were reported to be around $29,527,413, with almost 3 million units sold.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2012/HOBIT-DVD.php |title=The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey - Box Office Data, DVD and Blu-ray Sales, Movie News, Cast and Crew Information |publisher=The Numbers |date= |accessdate=16 May 2014}} An Extended Edition containing 13 minutes of additional footage and original music was released on [[3D Blu-ray]], DVD and Blu-ray on 5 November 2013 in the US, and on 11 November 2013 in the UK.{{cite web |last=Kinder |first=Kyle |url=http://www.geekexchange.com/the-hobbit-an-unexpected-journey-extended-edition-a-geek-dvdblu-ray-review-90901.html |title=The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey Extended Edition DVD/Blu-ray review - Geek Magazine |publisher=Geekexchange.com |date= |accessdate=16 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131112230909/http://www.geekexchange.com/the-hobbit-an-unexpected-journey-extended-edition-a-geek-dvdblu-ray-review-90901.html |archivedate=12 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }} ''The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug'' was released on DVD, 3D Blu-ray and Blu-ray on 7 April 2014 in the United Kingdom and on 8 April 2014 in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/the-hobbit-desolation-of-smaug-blu-ray-details-release-date/|title=THE HOBBIT: THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG Blu-ray Details Revealed; Set for April 8th Release in the U.S.|date=18 February 2014|work=Collider}} An Extended Edition containing 25 minutes of additional footage and original music{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/hobbit-third-movie-renamed-hobbit-battle-five-armies-1445943|title=Hobbit Finale Renamed The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies|author=Ben Skipper|work=International Business Times UK}} was released on 3 November 2014 in the UK, and on 4 November 2014 in the US.{{cite web|url = http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/The-Hobbit-The-Desolation-of-Smaug-Blu-ray/97693/#Review|title= The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug Blu-ray|date=2 November 2014 |work=Blu Ray.com|accessdate=11 November 2014}} ''The Hobbit: The Battle of The Five Armies'' was released on 3D Blu-ray, Blu-ray and DVD on 23 March 2015 in the United Kingdom and on 24 March in the United States.{{cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/movies-tv-shows/movies-tv-shows-on-sale/adventure/hobbit-the-the-motion-picture-trilogy/666421/|title=JB Hi-Fi - Hobbit, The: The Motion Picture Trilogy 6 Blu-Ray/ Ultraviolet|publisher=}}{{cite web|last=Nealey |first=Joshua |url=http://www.hypable.com/the-hobbit-the-battle-of-the-five-armies-dvd-blu-ray-release-date/|title=‘The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies’ DVD/Blu-ray release date, special features revealed|publisher=.hypable. |date= |accessdate=16 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/2015/03/24/3706611/the-hobbit-the-battle-of-the-five.html|title=‘The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies’ tops new DVD releases|work=thenewstribune}} An Extended Edition of the film containing 20 minutes of additional footage and original music was released on 17 November 2015 in the United States and on 23 November in the United Kingdom.{{cite web|url = http://www.comingsoon.net/dvd/features/633603-november-17-blu-ray-dvd-digital-hd#/slide/1|title= November 17, 2015: This Week on Blu-ray, DVD and Digital HD|date=2 November 2015 |work=Silas Lesnick|accessdate=17 November 2015}}{{cite web|url = http://www.themortonreport.com/entertainment/film/blu-ray-review-the-hobbit-the-battle-of-the-five-armies-extended-edition/|title= Exclusive clip from The Hobbit: The Battle Of The Five Armies Extended Edition|date=2 November 2015 |work=James Dyer|accessdate=11 November 2015}}{{cite web|url = http://www.empireonline.com/movies/news/exclusive-clip-hobbit-battle-five-armies-extended-edition/|title= Blu-ray Review: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Extended Edition|date=23 November 2015 |work=Chaz Lipp|accessdate=23 November 2015}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! $90.6M|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=23 December 2014|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|date=21 December 2014}} |} ===Accolades=== {{Main|List of accolades received by The Hobbit film series}} ''An Unexpected Journey'' has won the "Technical Achievement" award by the [[Houston Film Critics Society]], who also nominated it for "Best Original Song", the award for "Outstanding Virtual Cinematography" by the [[Visual Effects Society]], and the Empire Awards for [[Empire Award for Best Actor|"Best Actor"]] and [[Empire Award for Best Sci-Fi/Fantasy|"Best Sci-Fi/Fantasy"]].{{cite news |title=The 6th Annual Houston Film Critics Society Awards list of winners |work=[[Examiner.com]] |date=6 January 2013 |first=Chris |last=Gawin}}{{cite news|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/02/visual-effects-society-awards-2013-winners-list/ |title=VES Awards: ‘Life Of Pi’ Wins 4 Including Feature, ‘Brave’, ‘Game Of Thrones’ Other Big Winners |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=5 February 2013|accessdate=2 March 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/awards2013/winners/bestscififantasy.asp |title=Best Sci-Fi/Fantasy – The Hobbit an Unexpected Journey |work=[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]] |accessdate=26 March 2013 |date=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/awards2013/winners/bestactor.asp |title=Best Actor – Martin Freeman |work=[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]] |accessdate=26 March 2013 |date=}} Among others, the film has also received three [[Academy Award]] nominations, a nomination from the [[Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association]], four nominations from the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association]], six nominations from the [[Visual Effects Society]], and three nominations from the Phoenix Film Critics Society.{{cite web |url=http://www.adg.org/?store=art&setTheme=OFF&art=17_adg_awards_winnersB |title=17th Annual ADG Award Winners Announced |publisher=[[Art Directors Guild]] |accessdate=2 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226085736/http://www.adg.org/?store=art&setTheme=OFF&art=17_adg_awards_winnersB |archivedate=26 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.dcfilmcritics.com/awards/|title=The 2012 WAFCA Awards|publisher=dcfilmcritics.com|accessdate=2 March 2013|date=10 December 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.criticschoice.com/movie-awards/|title=18th Critics' Choice Awards|publisher=[[Broadcast Film Critics Association]]|accessdate=2 March 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://phoenixfilmcriticssociety.org/article/206/phoenix-film-critics-society-2012-annual-awards.html |title=Phoenix Film Critics Society 2012 Annual Awards |publisher=Phoenix Film Critics Society |accessdate=2 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128113349/http://phoenixfilmcriticssociety.org/article/206/phoenix-film-critics-society-2012-annual-awards.html |archivedate=28 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://phoenixfilmcriticssociety.org/article/204/phoenix-film-critics-society-2012-award-nominations.html |title=Phoenix Film Critics Society 2012 Award Nominations |publisher=Phoenix Film Critics Society |accessdate=2 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212065931/http://phoenixfilmcriticssociety.org/article/204/phoenix-film-critics-society-2012-award-nominations.html |archivedate=12 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }} ====Academy Awards==== * ''An Unexpected Journey'' — Nominations: 3; 1 award (non-competitive) * ''The Desolation of Smaug'' — Nominations: 3 * ''The Battle of the Five Armies'' - Nominations: 1 {| class="wikitable" style="margin:left;" |- ! style="width:214px;" rowspan="2"|Award ! colspan="3"|Film |- ! style="width:130px;"|''An Unexpected Journey'' ! style="width:130px;"|''The Desolation of Smaug'' ! style="width:130px;"|''The Battle of the Five Armies'' |- | '''Makeup and Hairstyling''' | {{nom}} | | |- | '''Production Design''' | {{nom}} | | |- | '''Sound Editing''' | | {{nom}} | {{nom}} |- | '''Sound Mixing''' | | {{nom}} | |- | '''Visual Effects''' | {{nom}} | {{nom}} | |- | '''Sci-Tech Award'''[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-21409266 The Hobbit picks up technical Oscar] - BBC | {{won}} | | |} ===Reaction to high frame rate=== At an industry event screening in April 2012, Peter Jackson showed a ten-minute clip of the film, and the new [[High Frame Rate]] 48 fps format received "an underwhelming reaction at best",{{cite web |date=24 April 2012 |title=CinemaCon 2012: Dim reaction to high-def look of Peter Jackson's 'The Hobbit'|url = http://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/04/24/cinemacon-2012-dim-reaction-to-high-def-look-of-peter-jacksons-the-hobbit/ | work = Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=26 April 2012}} while ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' stated that the footage "looked distinctively sharper and more immediate than everything shown before it, giving the 3D smoother movement and crisp sharpness". It also reported that it lost "the cinematic glow of the industry-standard 24 fps" and that "human actors seemed overlit and amplified in a way that many compared to modern sports broadcasts ... and daytime television".{{cite news|date= 24 April 2012|title= 'Hobbit' preview divides CinemaCon auds | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118053075|work= Variety|accessdate= 26 April 2012}} One projectionist complained that "it looked like a made-for-TV movie".{{cite news|date=25 April 2012|title=The Hobbit: first glimpse gets mixed response|url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/apr/25/the-hobbit-first-screening-cinemacon|work=The Guardian |accessdate= 26 April 2012|location=London|first=Ben|last=Child}} Peter Jackson claimed that the poor reception "wasn't particularly surprising" because "it does take you a while to get used to it. Ten minutes is sort of marginal, it probably needed a little bit more".{{cite news|date=29 April 2012|title= Jackson responds to critics| location = United Kingdom | work = News | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17885833 |publisher = BBC | accessdate = 30 April 2012}} However, once the entire film was released, many critics retained their complaints. While many noted the clarity and immediacy of the action scenes, they also criticised the picture quality as "hyper-real," clear enough to detect "painted sets" and "prosthetic noses".Travers, Peter (13 December 2012). [https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/the-hobbit-an-unexpected-journey-20121213 "The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey."] ''RollingStone.com''. Retrieved 11 February 2013.Mondello, Bob (13 December 2012). [https://www.npr.org/2012/12/13/166063975/a-hobbit-off-on-his-unhurried-journey?ft=1&f=1045 "A 'Hobbit,' Off On His Unhurried Journey."] ''NPR.org''. Retrieved 11 February 2013. Some critics did respond positively to the overall effect of the higher frame rate, saying it just takes a while to get used to – still allowing that the extra clarity can make some scenes look like "actors on a set rather than a scene in a movie".{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Examining-criticisms-of-The-Hobbit/tabid/1748/articleID/279188/Default.aspx |work=3 News NZ |title= Examining criticisms of The Hobbit|date= 5 December 2012}} ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey'' was also released in the current 24 fps standard in many theatres, some of which had not yet switched from film to digital projection.{{cite web |url= http://www.deadline.com/2012/07/comic-con-qa-peter-jackson-on-his-return-to-middle-earth-with-%E2%80%98the-hobbit%E2%80%99-and-how-48-frames-can-save-moviegoing/#more-301516 |title= Comic-Con Q&A: Peter Jackson on His Return to Middle Earth with 'The Hobbit' and How 48 Frames Can Save Moviegoing |first= Mike, Jr. |last= Fleming |work= [[Deadline Hollywood]] |date= 15 July 2012 |accessdate= 6 September 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120915114301/http://www.deadline.com/2012/07/comic-con-qa-peter-jackson-on-his-return-to-middle-earth-with-%E2%80%98the-hobbit%E2%80%99-and-how-48-frames-can-save-moviegoing/#more-301516 |archivedate= 15 September 2012 |df= dmy-all }} ===Derivative works=== ====Toys==== On 6 October 2011, [[Warner Bros.]] Consumer Products and U.S. toy company The Bridge Direct announced their partnership on worldwide master toy rights for ''The Hobbit'' films.Graser, Marc (6 October 2011). [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118044008 "WB hops on Bridge Direct"], ''Variety''. The toy line will include action figures, playsets and role-play accessories like swords and battle axes representing the characters and weapons in the films.{{cite web|url= http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=82992|title= Warner Bros. Makes deal for The Hobbit Toys| date= 6 October 2011|work= Coming soon |accessdate= 7 November 2012}}{{cite web|url= http://thefwoosh.com/2012/07/the-hobbit-an-unexpected-journey-action-figures-coming-this-fall-from-the-bridge-direct|title= The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey Action Figures|date= 10 July 2012|work= The fwoosh|accessdate= 7 November 2012|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130204030328/http://thefwoosh.com/2012/07/the-hobbit-an-unexpected-journey-action-figures-coming-this-fall-from-the-bridge-direct|archivedate= 4 February 2013|df= dmy-all}} The first wave of toy products hit store shelves in October 2012, ahead of the release of ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey''. U.S. retailers that carry the toy line include [[Toys "R" Us]], [[Kmart]], and [[Walmart]]. [[Games Workshop]] released miniatures from ''The Hobbit'' as part of The Lord of the Rings Strategy Battle Game. The company has had rights to produce miniatures from the original book for some years but has not released any lines, save for a stand-alone game based on the Battle of Five Armies, with original designs not related to ''The Lord of the Rings'' films.{{cite web | url = http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2012/09/24/62227-hobbit-toys-hit-store-shelves-tauriel-revealed/ | title = Hobbit toys hit stores | date = 24 September 2012| work = TheOneRing.net | accessdate = 7 November 2012}} While a number of companies were vying for ''The Hobbit'' deal, Warner Bros. Consumer Products awarded the license to Bridge Direct partly because some of its execs and staffers had worked on ''The Lord of the Rings'' toy line during their tenure at other toy companies, including [[Toy Biz]] and [[Play Along]]. The Bridge Direct, run by toy business veteran [[Jay Foreman (businessman)|Jay Foreman]], is best known for toys such as Inkoos activity plush, and the [[Zhu Zhu Pets]] plush line. On 16 December 2011, [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Consumer Products]] and [[Lego]] announced the development of figures and play sets based on the upcoming adaptations of ''The Hobbit'' as well as ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|The Lord of the Rings]]''. The launch of the ''[[Middle-earth Lego sets|Lego The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey]]'' was released to coincide with the release of the film adaptation's first part in December 2012.{{cite press release|title=Building Sets Based on Epic Film Trilogy and Forthcoming Theatrical Release Slated for 2012|publisher=[[Lego]] |date=16 December 2011 |url= http://aboutus.lego.com/en-us/news-room/2011/december/warner-bros-consumer-products-and-the-lego-group/ |accessdate=3 March 2012}} ====Video games==== Following the expiration in 2008 of [[Electronic Arts]]' license to ''The Lord of the Rings'', [[Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment]] acquired the rights to develop a video game based on ''The Hobbit''.{{Cite news|url = http://www.gamespot.com/articles/report-warner-bros-lording-over-rings-ip/1100-6206033/|title=Lord of the Rings game rights now at Warner Bros | work =Variety |date=12 March 2009 |accessdate=15 February 2015}} When Guillermo del Toro was set to direct he had stated that a video game, if it were to be made, would not be released to tie-in with ''The Hobbit'' film, but rather after their release. Del Toro had stated that while he would like to be involved in the video game's creation, making it at the same time as the film would complicate things due to a "tight schedule".{{cite web |first= Andrei | last = Dumitrescu |url= http://news.softpedia.com/news/Hobbit-Videogame-Not-Arriving-Alongside-Movie-113957.shtml |title= Hobbit Videogame Not Arriving Alongside Movie |publisher=Softpedia |date=12 June 2009 |accessdate=27 March 2011}} In October 2011, Warner Bros. confirmed that a ''Hobbit'' video game would be released in 2012, before the first film's release.{{Cite news| title = Warner's approach to video games is paying off |url= http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-1018-ct-warner-interactive-20111018,0,7733264.story |first=Ben|last=Fritz |date=18 October 2011 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate= 19 October 2011}} However, the studio did not confirm whether or not the game would be a tie-in with the film.{{Cite news |title= Report: ''Lego Batman 2'', ''The Hobbit'' and DC Comic games releasing in 2012 |url= http://www.vg247.com/2011/10/18/report-lego-batman-2-the-hobbit-and-dc-comics-game-in-the-works-for-2012/ |first=Stephany|last=Nunneley |date=18 October 2011 |work= [[VG247]]| accessdate =19 October 2011}} Warner Brothers developed two free-to-play online strategy games in collaboration with [[Kabam]] for promoting the film series which were ''The Hobbit: Kingdoms of Middle Earth'' released for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[iOS]] on 8 November 2012 and ''The Hobbit: Armies of the Third Age'' playable online on web browsers and as a [[Facebook app]] that was released on 21 March 2013.{{cite web|url= https://venturebeat.com/2012/09/25/kabam-to-make-social-and-mobile-games-based-on-the-hobbit-film/|title= Kabam to make social and mobile games based on The Hobbit film|author= Dean Takahashi|publisher= [[VentureBeat]]|date= 25 September 2012|accessdate= 26 July 2014}}{{cite web|url= http://www.technologytell.com/apple/107572/the-hobbit-kingdoms-of-middle-earth-now-out-for-ios-android/|title= The Hobbit: Kingdoms of Middle Earth now out for iOS, Android|author= Bill Stiteler|publisher= TechnologyTell|date= 8 November 2012|accessdate= 26 July 2014}}{{cite web|url= http://www.vg247.com/2013/03/21/the-hobbit-armies-of-the-third-age-now-available-for-browsers-facebook/|title= The Hobbit: Armies of the Third Age now available for browsers, Facebook|author= Stephany Nunneley|publisher= [[VG247]]|date= 21 March 2013|accessdate= 26 July 2014}} [[Monolith Productions]] developed ''[[Guardians of Middle-earth]]'',{{Citation | url = http://www.guardiansofmiddleearth.com/ | archive-url = https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120807215035/http://www.guardiansofmiddleearth.com/lang_select | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 7 August 2012 | title = Guardians of Middle-earth | publisher = Monolith | df = dmy-all }} which was released on 4 December 2012 for [[PlayStation 3]] via the [[PlayStation Network]], and 5 December 2012 for [[Xbox 360]] via [[Xbox Live Arcade]]. ''Guardians of Middle-earth'' delivers a multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) game set in Middle-earth and crafted specifically for the console systems. Gamers can play in teams of up to 10 players in strategic five versus five competitive multiplayer battle arenas in the epic setting of Middle-earth. Players can develop and master more than 20 guardians, including Gandalf, Sauron, Gollum and many more, forming memorable and unlikely alliances with and against friends. Gamers can connect via an in-game voice communication system, as well as access a comprehensive online stat and leader board system where they can track friends’ victories and defeats. The game featured tie-ins to the released ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey'' motion picture which released on 14 December 2012. On 25 November, Warner Brothers confirmed ''[[Lego The Hobbit (video game)|Lego The Hobbit]]'' video game. The game's levels only took place in the first two films. The game was released 8 April 2014.Larsen, Luke (25 November 2013). "[http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/11/25/lego-the-hobbit-game-could-be-coming-in-2014 LEGO Hobbit Game Confirmed for Spring 2014]." ''[[IGN]]''. Retrieved 26 September 2013. Two video games were developed to coincide with the film's theatrical release. {{Main|The_Hobbit:_The_Battle_of_the_Five_Armies#Video_games|l1=The Hobbit: Battle of the Five Armies - Fight for Middle Earth}} A tie-in fighting video game was released simultaneously with the film for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[iOS]] platforms which received negative reviews from critics and users. {{Main|Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor}} ''Shadow of Mordor'' was a critically acclaimed [[Action-adventure]] video game released for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]] & [[Xbox One]] in October 2014 and for [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] on 21 November, nearly a week prior to ''[[The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies]]'' world [[premiere]] in London, on 1 December. The events of the game take place directly after [[Sauron]] fled to [[Mordor]], escaping [[The White Council]], which was shown at the beginning of the film. The game was planned to act as an overlap between The Hobbit and [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|The Lord of the Rings]]. ====Other Versions==== In January 2015 a fan going by the name of "TolkienEditor" recut the three Hobbit films into a single, four-and-a-half-hour film that removed much content that many fans had complained about. Much of this material was seen as superfluous, admittedly added by Jackson at the request of the studio, in order to make the films more appealing to a wider audience.{{cite web|url=https://kottke.org/15/01/the-hobbit-the-tolkien-edit|title=The Hobbit: The Tolkien Edit|publisher=}} This was quickly followed by several other fan made editions with different approaches and lengths.{{cite web|url=https://ifdb.fanedit.org/fanedit-search/tag/franchise/lord-of-the-rings/?criteria=2|title=FanEdit.org Lord of the Rings franchise data base.|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.maple-films.com/jrr-tolkiens-the-hobbit|title=JRR Tolkien's The Hobbit by Maple Films|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://definitivehobbitcut.tumblr.com/|title=There and Back Again: A Hobbit's Tale Recut|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://thehobbitdwarfededition.tumblr.com/|title=The Hobbit: Dwarfed Edition|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://hobbitfanedit.wixsite.com/ironfoot|title=The Hobbit: Ironfoot Edition|publisher=}} ==Notes== {{refbegin}} # {{note|1}}Although the scene in Gollum's cave was shot in a studio in New Zealand, Harwoods Hole was used for the background shots. {{refend}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{Citation | author-link = Brian Sibley | first = Brian | last = Sibley | title = Peter Jackson: A Film-maker's Journey | publisher = [[HarperCollins]] | year = 2006 | location = London | isbn = 0-00-717558-2}}. ==External links== {{Wikiquote|The Hobbit (movies)}} * {{Official website|http://www.thehobbit.com}} * {{Citation | url = http://www.thehobbitblog.com | title = The Hobbit | type = official studio blog}} * {{Tolkien Gateway|The Hobbit (film series)}} {{The Lord of the Rings & The Hobbit film series}} {{Middle-earth films}} {{Hobbit}} {{Peter Jackson}} {{Guillermo del Toro}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hobbit (film series), The}} [[Category:The Hobbit (film series)| ]] [[Category:2010s 3D films]] [[Category:American fantasy films]] [[Category:New Zealand films]] [[Category:American epic films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films about dragons]] [[Category:Prequel films]] [[Category:Motion capture in film]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Film series introduced in 2012]] [[Category:Films shot in New Zealand]] [[Category:Films directed by Peter Jackson]] [[Category:Screenplays by Guillermo del Toro]] [[Category:WingNut Films films]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:New Line Cinema films]] [[Category:Fictional-language films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2010s fantasy films]] [[Category:Films scored by Howard Shore]] [[Category:American 3D films]] [[Category:New Zealand 3D films]] [[Category:New Zealand epic films]] [[Category:Films released in separate parts]]

[[Category:Culture-related timelines|Architectural styles]] [[Category:Architecture lists]] [[Category:Architectural styles|+]] [[Category:Architectural design|+]] [[Category:Architectural history|+]] [[Category:Design-related lists]] [[Category:Graphical timelines|Architectural styles]]

'''Traditional witchcraft''' is a term used to refer to a variety of contemporary forms of [[witchcraft]]. Pagan studies scholar Ethan Doyle White described it as "a broad movement of aligned magico-religious groups who reject any relation to [[Gerald Gardner (Wiccan)|Gardner]]ianism and the wider [[Wicca]]n movement, claiming older, more "traditional" roots. Although typically united by a shared aesthetic rooted in European folklore, the Traditional Craft contains within its ranks a rich and varied array of occult groups, from those who follow a contemporary Pagan path that is suspiciously similar to Wicca to those who adhere to [[Luciferianism]]".{{sfn|Doyle White|2011|pp=205–206}}
According to British Traditional Witch Michael Howard, the term refers to "any non-Gardnerian, non-Alexandrian, non-Wiccan or pre-modern form of the Craft, especially if it has been inspired by historical forms of witchcraft and folk magic".<ref>[[#How11|Howard 2011]]. p. 15.</ref> Another definition was offered by Daniel A. Schulke, the current Magister of the Cultus Sabbati, when he proclaimed that ''traditional witchcraft'' "refers to a coterie of initiatory lineages of ritual magic, spellcraft and devotional mysticism".<ref>[[#Sch06|Schulke 2006]].</ref>
Some forms of traditional witchcraft are the [[Feri Tradition]], [[Cochrane's Craft]] and the [[Witchcraft (contemporary)#Sabbatic Craft|Sabbatic craft]].<ref>[[#How11|Howard 2011]]. p. 17.</ref>
In 1981, three pseudonymous authors published ''Wicca: The Ancient Way'', in which they used ''traditional witchcraft'' to refer to [[Gardnerian Wicca]].<ref name="DoyleWhite197">[[#Doy10|Doyle White 2010]]. p. 197.</ref>
== Cochrane’s Craft == Cochrane’s Craft, which is also known as Cochranianism, is a tradition of traditional witchcraft founded in 1951 by the [[English people|English]] Witch [[Robert Cochrane (witch)|Robert Cochrane]], who himself claimed to have been taught it by some of his elderly family members, a claim that is disputed by some historians such as [[Ronald Hutton]] and [[Leo Ruickbie]].
Cochranianism revolved around the veneration of the [[Horned God]] and the [[Mother Goddess]], alongside seven [[polytheism|polytheistic]] deities which are viewed as children of the God and Goddess. Cochranian Witchcraft has several features that separate it from other traditions such as [[Gardnerian Wicca]], such as its emphasis on [[mysticism]] and [[philosophy]], and Cochrane's attitude that it was not [[Paganism|pagan]], but only based upon paganism.<ref name="Roebuck">{{cite book | first=Mike | last=Howard | authorlink= | title=The Roebuck in the Thicket: An Anthology of the Robert Cochrane Witchcraft Tradition | publisher = Capall Bann| year=2001}} Chapter One.</ref>
== Feri Tradition == The [[Feri Tradition]] (which is a different tradition than Faery, Fairy, Faerie, or Vicia) is an initiatory tradition of [[Witchcraft]] distinct from Wicca. It is an [[ecstasy (state)|ecstatic]] (rather than [[fertility]]) tradition stemming from the experience of Cora and [[Victor Anderson (poet)|Victor Anderson]]. Strong emphasis is placed on sensual experience and awareness, including sexual mysticism, which is not limited to heterosexual expression.<ref name=Korn>"The Faery Tradition" ©1988, 1995, 2000 Anna Korn</ref> The Feri Tradition has very diverse influences, such as [[Huna (New Thought)|Huna]], [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]], [[Fairy|Faery lore]], [[Kabbalah]], [[Hoodoo (folk magic)|Hoodoo]], [[Tantra]], and [[Gnosticism]].
Among the distinguishing features of the Feri tradition is the use of a specific Feri power or energetic current.<ref name=Korn/> Feri witches often see themselves as "fey": outside social definitions and intentionally living within paradox. They believe that much of reality is unseen, or at least has uncertain boundaries. Within the tradition there is a deep respect for the wisdom of nature, a love of beauty, and an appreciation of bardic and mantic creativity.
Core teachings acknowledged by most branches of the tradition include the concepts of the Three Souls and the Black Heart of Innocence, the tools of the Iron and Pearl Pentacle (now commonly also used by [[Reclaiming (Neopaganism)]]), as well as an awareness of "energy ecology", which admonishes practitioners to never give away or waste their personal power. Trance experiences and personal connection to the Divine are at the heart of this path, leading to a wide variety of practices throughout the larger body of the tradition.
In his study of Wicca, Pagan studies scholar Ethan Doyle White characterised Feri as a "Wiccan" tradition.{{sfn|Doyle White|2016|p=46}} He noted however that some practitioners of modern Pagan Witchcraft restrict the term "Wicca" to [[British Traditional Wicca]], in which case Feri would not be classified as "Wicca"; he deemed this exclusionary definition of the term to be "unsuitable for academic purposes".{{sfn|Doyle White|2016|p=161}} Instead, he characterised Feri as one form of Wicca which is nevertheless distinct from others, such as British Traditional Wicca, [[Dianic Wicca]], and [[Stregheria]].{{sfn|Doyle White|2016|p=162}}
== Sabbatic craft == {{Anchor|Sabbatic|Sabbatic Craft|Sabbatic witchcraft}}
Sabbatic craft, a term coined by [[Andrew D. Chumbley]], is described as "an initiatory line of spirit-power that can inform all who are receptive to its impetus, and which{{spaced ndash}}when engaged with beyond names{{spaced ndash}}may be understood as a Key unto the Hidden Design of Arte."<ref name="Chumbley2002a"> {{cite journal |last = Chumbley |first = Andrew D. |authorlink = Andrew D. Chumbley |last2 = Howard |first2 = Michael |last3 = Fitzgerald |first3 = Robert |title = An Interview with Andrew D. Chumbley |journal = The Cauldron |number = 103 |date = February 2002 |url = http://www.orakels.org/media/occult/Wicca/Interview_with_Andrew_Chumbley.pdf |quote = In essence, the Crooked Path Teachings intend a direct means of autonomous initiation into the Knowledge of the Magical Quintessence. }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> Chumbley sometimes referred to the ''Nameless Faith'',<ref name="Chumbley2002b">{{cite journal |last = Chumbley |first = Andrew D. |authorlink = Andrew D. Chumbley |title = Cultus Sabbati: Provenance, Dream and Magistry |journal = The Cauldron |number = 104 |date = May 2002 |url = http://www.xoanon.co.uk/xoanoncultussabbati.php |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100619030458/http://www.xoanon.co.uk/xoanoncultussabbati.php |archivedate = 2010-06-19 |df = }}</ref> ''Crooked Path'', and ''Via Tortuosa''.<ref name="Chumbley2002a"/><ref name="Schulke2006">{{cite journal |last = Schulke |first = Daniel A. |title = Way and Waymark—Considerations of Exilic Wisdom in the Old Craft |journal = The Cauldron |number = 122 |date = November 2006 |url = http://www.xoanon.co.uk/xoanonwayandwaymark.php |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110728050303/http://www.xoanon.co.uk/xoanonwayandwaymark.php |archivedate = 2011-07-28 |df = }}</ref> He reserved "Sabbatic Craft" as a unifying term to refer to the "convergent lineages"<ref name="Chumbley2002a"/> of the "Cultus Sabbati," a body of traditional witchcraft initiates.<ref name="Schulke2006"/>
Chumbley's works and those of Daniel Schulke on the Cultus Sabbati's "ongoing tradition of sorcerous wisdom"<ref name="Chumbley2002b"/> continue to serve as the prototypical reference works. The craft is not an ancient, pre-Christian tradition surviving into the modern age. It is a tradition rooted in "[[cunning-craft]]," a patchwork of older magical practice and later Christian mythology.
{{Quote|‘Sabbatic Craft’ describes a corpus of magical practices which self-consciously utilize the imagery and mythos of the "[[Witches' Sabbath]]" as a cipher of ritual, teaching and gnosis. This is not the same as saying that one practises the self-same rituals in the self-same manner as the purported early modern "witches" or historically attested [[cunning folk]], rather it points toward the fact that the very mythos which had been generated about both "witches" and their "ritual gatherings" has been appropriated and re-orientated by contemporary successors of cunning-craft observance, and then knowingly applied for their own purposes.|[[Andrew D. Chumbley|Andrew Chumbley]] defining Sabbatic Craft<ref name="Chumbley2002a"/>}}
In his [[grimoire]] ''Azoëtia'', Chumbley incorporated diverse iconography from ancient [[History of Sumer|Sumerian]], [[ancient Egypt]]ian, [[Yezidi]], and [[Aztec]] cultures.<ref name="Schulke2006"/> He spoke of a patchwork of [[veneration of the dead|ancestral]] and [[tutelary spirit|tutelary]] spirit [[folklore]] which he perceived amidst diverse "Old Craft" traditions in [[United Kingdom|Britain]] as "a gnostic faith in the Divine Serpent of Light, in the Host of the Gregori, in the Children of Earth sired by the Watchers, in the lineage of descent via Lilith, Mahazael, Cain, Tubal-cain, Naamah, and the Clans of the Wanderers."<ref name="Chumbley2002a"/> Schulke believed that [[folk magic|folk]] and cunning-crafts of Britain absorbed [[multicultural]] elements from "[[Freemasonry]], [[bibliomancy|Bible divination]], [[Romany people|Romany]] charms, and other diverse streams,"<ref name="Schulke2006"/> what Chumbley called "dual-faith observance," referring to a "co-mingling of ‘native’ forms of British magic and [[Christianity]]".<ref name="Schulke2006"/>
